questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Middle meatus

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.

•	Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder’s neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. 

•	The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to Rhinolalia clausa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nasal polyp

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	Rhinolalia clausa is hyponasality. This is due to nasal obstruction, nasal polyp, sinusitis, adenoid hypertrophy, angiofibroma.

•	Rhinolalia aperta is hypernasality. This is due to cleft palate, palatal perforation, palatal palsy, palatal weakness ( velopharyngeal insufficiency), submucosa cleft palate, bifid uvula.

questions.text: A patient complaing of chronic nasal obstruction since last 6 months was operated 2 months back and now present with crusts and bleeding.Study the nasal examination image and comment on the surgery which was done ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

SMR.

Ref: Read the text below

Sol

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Maxillary sinus

questions.text: A roomy nasal cavity filled with foul smelling crusts with disfigured hard woody nose is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rhinoscleroma

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Rhinoscleroma:

Definition: Chronic, progressive granu- lomatous infection of external nose, nasal cavity and upper lip area. This can also involve larynx ( scleroma Larynx) Organism:	Klebsiella	rhinoscleromatis (Gram negative: Frisch 
Bacillus).

It is more common in northern part of In- dia

Clinical Picture:

1.	Atrophic Stage

Atrophic changes occur in the floor of the nose, septum and turbinates. This stage resembles atrophic rhinitis.

2.	Granulomatous Stage:

Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and the upper lip (woody Nose)

3.	Cicatrical Stage: in this stage due to fi- brosis, patient develops cosmetic deformity

( Tapir nose) Diagnosis:

Submucosal infiltration of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells & Russel bodies

Mikulicz Cells:

Large foam cells with a central nucleus & vacuolated cytoplasm (contain the bacilli) Russell Bodies:

Eccentric nucleus and a pink- staining cy- toplasm- Look like plasma cells.

Treatment:

1.	Streptomycin

2.	Tetracyline

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with recurrent sinusitis. Surgical intervention is advised for this patient. Which of the following is gold standard investigation before endoscopic surgery like functional endoscopic sinus surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CT scan

Sol :  

•	CT scan of sinuses will tell the extent of disease, predisposing structural abnormalities, amount of destruction of bony walls and any extension to orbit and cranial cavity.

•	Investigation of choice for diagnosis of sinusitis is also CT scan.

questions.text: Guerin Sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Guerin's sign is bruising in the palate in the region of the greater palatine arteries. We present a patient who sustained blunt facial trauma and as a result had a mobile maxilla and a severe malocclusion

choices.text: Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Bed rest and avoiding strenuous activity

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. 

•	Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

questions.text: A 7 year old child while playing fell down. He has developed nasal blockage on both sides and there is swelling around the nose. What is the further treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aspiration of septal swelling

Sol :  

•	This is a case of traumatic septal hematoma. 

•	The treatment is immediate aspiration or drainage of hematoma else it can lead to septal abscess and finally to septal perforation

questions.text: Onodi cells and Haller cells of ethmoid are related respectively to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Optic nerve, orbital floor

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

These are variations of ethmoidal air cells. Haller cell is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells and they lie in relation to orbital floor.

Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid and lie in relation to optic nerve. When present they can increase the chance of complications during FESS. Another variation of ethmoid air cells is Concha bullosa which meAns pneuma- tised middle turbinate.

Few points about normal ethmoid air cells

•	Anterior ethmoid air cells are from 2-8. Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8

•	Anterior and posterior ethmoid cells are separated by basal lamella =ground lamella

•	Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell.

•	Bulla ethmoidalis is the most constant and largest anterior ethmoid air cell

questions.text: 42 yrs old male having chronic history of bronchial asthma, sinusitis and samter’s triad. Which of the following drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aspirin 

YOUNG SYNDROME

a.    Chronic Rhinosinusitis

b.    Azoospermia

c.    Bronchiectasis.

Samter's triad (ST) is a well-known disease characterized by the triad of bronchial asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin intolerance.

questions.text: A 29 year old HIV positive individual presents to emergency in a critical state with deranged vitals. The examination shows a blackish necrotic debris in the nasal cavity with necrosed skin of external nose. What is the best treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amphotericin B + Debridement

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral phycomycosis):

1.	Is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection

2.	Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopus oryzae

3.	Predisposing factors: immunosup- pressed patients (HIV), uncontrolled young diabetics

Features:

1.	Remarkable affinity for blood vessels- arteries

2.	Leads to extensive endothelial damage & thrombosis

Findings:

The disease begins in the nose, invade →

P.N.S → orbit →cribiform plate→ menin- ges → brain

Typical Finding

1.	Black necrotic mass seen filling the en- tire nasal cavity

2.	Erosion of the nasal septrum and the hard palate may be appreciable

There is anesthesia over face, nose with reduced mucosal bleeding

M.R.I. Detects early vascular and intrac- ranial invasion

Treatment:

•	Systemic amphotericin ( Liposomal)

•	Local debridement

questions.text: The most common long term complication of Functional endoscopic sinus surgery Atrophic rhinitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intranasal synechiae formation

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	The most common long term complication of any nasal surgery is synechaie forma- tion in nose (adhesions) .

•	Topical application of Mitomycin C is help- ful to reduce synechiae formation since this drug has antifibroblastic properties.

choices.text: It is benign but has malignant potential
It is malignant and do not metastasize

questions.text: True about inverted papilloma arising from lateral wall of nose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is benign but has malignant potential

Sol :  

•	Inverted papilloma, which arises from the mucosa of lateral wall of nose, most frequently affects males in the age group of 30-5O years. 

•	It is benign but has malignant potential

•	Only 10-15% are associated with malignancy. 

•	Treatment is complete excision which amounts to medial maxillectomy. 

•	Post-operative radiotherapy is not necessary.

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient presenting with nasal mass (see the image) and epistaxis. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rhinosposridiosis

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Rhinosporidiosis

Organism: Rhinosporidium seeberi— Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic pro- tozoa of the class- mesomycetozoea ( ponds water)

Distribution: India (Southern parts), Sri lanka

Sites

1.	Most commonly: Nose and Nasopharynx

2.	Others: oral cavity, conjunctiva, genital mucosa

The disease is trAnsmitted through contaminated water of ponds

Lesions:

Mulberry like polypoidal mass in the nose with epistaxis is typical presentation

Diagnosis: Biopsy Treatment:

Complete excision of the mass with a cutting diathermy and cauterization of its base.

Medical management: Dapsone is a useful drug to prevent recurrence

questions.text: 35 yrs old patient with nasal epistaxis in epistaxis in emergency which was not controlled by nasal package or any other initial maneuver. Next step in the management will be ligation of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sphenopalatine.

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

choices.text: Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Shift patient to OT and cautery.
Use hemostatic agents do 3 to 4 gargles per day

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Primary haemorrhage. 

•	Occurs at the time of operation.

•	It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 

•	Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.

•	Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).

Secondary haemorrhage. 

•	Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 

•	It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Semicircular canal

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	The semicircular canals that are a part of the bony labyrinth are responsible for balance and equilibrium.

•	The semicircular canals are three loop-shaped structures filled with endolymph fluid and lined with hair cells that detect angular acceleration in three planes (horizontal, vertical, and oblique).

choices.text: Internal carotid artery lies in relation to anterior wall of middle ear
Pyramid lies on the posterior wall
Aqueduct of coclea connects endolymph to the endolymphatic sac
Mesotympanum is the narrowest part of middle ear

questions.text: All of the following are true about anatomy of ear except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aqueduct of coclea connects endolymph to the endolymphatic sac

Reference – Read the text below

Sol : 

•	Middle ear has three parts- epitympanum, mesotympanum and hypotympanum. The narrowest part is mesotympanum where as the deepest part is epitympanum, which is also called as attic. Attic is covered by outer attic bony wall which is also called as scutum.

•	ICA  lies in relation to anterior wall and jugular bulb lies in relation to floor of middle ear. At times jugular bulb can be dehiscent. 

•	Pyramid lies on the posterior wall from where stapedius muscle tendon arises

•	Cochlear aqueduct connects perilymph to CSF.

questions.text: A patient with ear wax underwent syringing. During syringing, patient developed syncopal episode. Stimulation of which nerve is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arnold's nerve

Sol :  

•	The nerve responsible for a vasovagal attack during syringing of the ear is Arnold nerve branch of vagus nerve. 

•	Stimulation of the vagus nerve, such as during syringing of the ear, can cause a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to a vasovagal attack.

choices.text: Sensory end organ of Utricle and saccule
Sensory end organ of semicircular canals

questions.text: Cupula in inner ear is located in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gelatinous layer around Crist

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	Crista is the sensory end organ of semi- circular canals. It lies in Ampulla of canals which is a dilated end of SCC. Crista is surrounded by gelatinous layer called Cupula.

•	Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of macula. Macula is the sensory end organ of utricle and saccule whose function is linear acceleration.

questions.text: Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week ,Saccule develops from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pars inferior

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	Cochlea and vestibule begin to develop by 3 rd week of IUL and finish by 16th week 

•	Auditory placode forming near hindbrain invaginates to form otocyst- forms all the inner ear structures

•	Pars superior- utricle and semicircular canals

•	Pars inferior- saccule and cochlea , Also endolymphatic duct and sac

questions.text: Ostmann fat pads are associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Eustachian tube

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	The Ostmann fat pads are masses of fatty tissues located inferolateral to the cartilaginous eustachian tubes.

•	It helps keep the tube closed, protecting it from the reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and also prevents the transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear.

choices.text: Most common site of facial palsy

questions.text: Study the Fig ,Comment on the importance of pointed space :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Most common site for cholesteatoma

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:

•	Prussak's Space is the small middle ear recess, bordered laterally by the flaccid part of Shrapnell's membrane, superiorly by the scutum and lateral malleal ligament, inferiorly by the lateral process of the malleus, and medially by the neck of the malleus is most common site for cholesteatoma

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation with perforated tympanic membrane
Erosion of stapes footplate with perforated tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant female presents with conductive hearing loss of 54db, not associated with tinnitus. Pure tone audiometry shows a notch at 2000 Hz. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathophysiology of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	The given clinical scenario of a young pregnant female with bilateral conducting hearing loss and notch at 2000Hz (Carhart’s notch) is suggestive of otosclerosis where there is an ossicular fixation with the intact tympanic membrane.

•	Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. 

•	It is more commonly seen in fernales between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. 

•	It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safe limit of noise levels in a city
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

45 dB

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•	Noise travels through the air. Noise is measured in decibels.

•	Experts believe that continuous noise levels in excess of 90 decibels can cause loss of hearing and irreversible changes in nervous systems.

•	The World Health Organization [WHO] has fixed 45 decibels as the safe noise level for a city.

questions.text: A patient with autophony has a hypermobile tympanic membrane. what is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patulous Eustachian tube

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•	Patulous Eustachian tube, also known as patent Eustachian tube, is the name of a physical disorder where the Eustachian tube, which is normally closed, instead stays intermittently open. 

•	When this occurs, the patient experiences autophony, the hearing of self-generated sounds. 

•	These sounds, such as one's own breathing, voice, and heartbeat, vibrate directly onto the ear drum and can create a "bucket on the head" effect.

choices.text: Superior olivary nucleus ,Cochlear nuclei pathway ,Lateral lemniscus,Inferior colliculus
Cochlear nuclei pathway ,Superior olivary nucleus,Lateral lemniscus,Inferior colliculus
Inferior colliculus ,Cochlear nuclei pathway ,Superior olivary nucleus,Lateral lemniscus
Lateral lemniscus,Cochlear nuclei pathway ,Superior olivary nucleus ,Inferior colliculus

questions.text: Which of the following is true sequence of auditory pathway:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Cochlear nuclei pathway ,Superior olivary nucleus,Lateral lemniscus,Inferior colliculus.

Ref: Read the text below

Sol.

    Eighth nerve for auditory 
    C – Cochlear nuclei pathway 
    O – Superior olivary nucleus
    L – Lateral lemniscus
    I – Inferior colliculus
    M – Medial geniculate body
    A – Auditory cortex.

questions.text: Identify the incision shown the given image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wilde’s incision

Reference – Read the text below

Sol : 

•	Wilde's incision – This post-aural incision is used for a variant mastoiditis drainage, and was named after Sir William Wilde, an ENT surgeon in Dubli

•	Tympanomeatal flap is raised to expose the middle ear in endomeatal approach

•	Rosen’s incision is used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy

•	It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy.

questions.text: Sign shown in the given otoscopic image is hallmark feature of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Otosclerosis

Explanation:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with the following audiogram. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Otosclerosis

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	In this PTA, there is AB gap which is suggestive of conductive hearing loss

•	Dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis ( Carhart’s Notch) Dip at 4000 Hz in AC and BC curve in audiogram is suggestive of noise induced hearing loss

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with Tinnitus, vertigo and fluctuating hearing loss. His Audiogram given below . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meniere's disease 

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:


	Episodic vertigo and fluctuant sensorineural hearing loss are features of Meniere’s disease. 

	Low frequency hearing loss is the audiometry finding

	It is associated with tinnitus, which is usually a low pitched roaring or hissing sound. Pulsatile tinnitus is not a feature of Meniere’s disease and occurs with conditions like arteriovenous malformations of the temporal bone, glomus tumor, etc.

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.

•	Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. 

•	The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. 

•	The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible,or latest by 6 months of age.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic consults a physician because of severe and persistent earache. Otoscopic examination demonstrates foul-smelling purulent otorrhea and a red mass lesion of the external ear canal. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates granulation tissue rather than tumor. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa 

Sol:

•	External otitis, or infection of the external ear canal, can be caused by a variety of organisms, notably including Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, and Staphylococcus aureus. There is, however, a severe subtype of external otitis, malignant external otitis, of which you should be aware. This form is specifically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and tends to affect elderly diabetics and AIDS patients, causing the findings illustrated in the question stem. It is particularly worrisome both because the Pseudomonas organism is so tissue destructive and because it is often highly resistant to most intravenous antibiotics. (Consult your local microbiology or pharmacology departments for advice about local sensitivities if you encounter the condition.) Complications can be devastating, including deafness, facial nerve paralysis, osteomyelitis, and meningitis. 

•	Escherichia coli can cause both external otitis and acute otitis media, but does not usually cause malignant external otitis. 

•	Haemophilus influenza is an important cause of acute otitis media. 

Proteus vulgaris can cause external otitis, but does not usually cause the malignant form.

questions.text: 6 yr old child bought by mom with history of loss of hearing in one ear since 2 months .Study the the given otoscopic finding and comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serous otitis Media

•	Most cases of bullous myringitis occur in males between the ages of 2 to 8 years old, whereas AOM is most commonly seen in children less than two years of age

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency with high grade fever, seizure and altered sensorium. On history he was known case of CSOM and was under treatment. and was undergoing CSOM treatment. Immediate CT was done. Choose the most appropriate Diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Temporal lobe abscess Ref: Read the text below Sol: Otogenic Brain Abscess:  Temporal lobe abscess: Cerebellar abscess = 2:1.  Organisms: Commonest: Anaerobic streptococci.  Nominal Aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, focal epilepsy. Mastoidectomy: Canal wall down (CWD) procedures: • Modified radical mastoidectomy • Radical mastoidectomy • Atticotomy Canal wall up (CWU) procedures: • Cortical mastoidectomy (Schwartz operation) Combined approach tympanoplasty

questions.text: A patient presented with pain around mastoid, and positive reservoir sign. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mastoiditis

Sol :  

Mastoiditis Symptoms

•	Pain behind the ear seen

•	Fever: Persistence of fever in otitis media → resemble development of mastoiditis

•	Ear discharge - profuse

Signs

•	Ear Discharge - mucopurulent profuse

•	Mastoid tenderness

•	Mastoid swelling

•	Reservoir sign - meatus immediately fills with pus after it has been mopped out

•	Sagging of posterosuperior wall

•	Perforation of tympanic

•	membrane small pertora at para tensa

•	Hearing loss - conductive type hearing loss

Treatment

•	Hospitalize the patient

•	Antibiotics Amoxicillin

•	Myringotonny

•	Cortical Mastoidectomy in these cases

choices.text: Hearing aids may be difficult to fit postoperatively.
Need for regular cleaning of defect created
Low tolerance for water exposure postoperatively

questions.text: Disadvantages of CWD mastoidectomy include all the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Higher rate of residual/recurrent disease

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	CWD mastoidectomy carries the following advantages: better operative exposure, easier detection of residual disease at second-look surgery, lower recidivism rates.

•	CWD is associated with slower healing times, necessitates chronic postoperative bowl cleaning, is more susceptible to infection, and necessitates that the patient avoid water activities.

•	The use of conventional hearing aids after CWD mastoidectomy may be problematic.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gradenigo’s syndrome

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

- Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)

- Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)

- Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinnes test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glomus tumour

Sol :  

                          Glomus Tumors (Paragangliomas, Chemodectomas)

Glomus Tumor: slow growing, benign tumor although locally destructive (expansive, bone eroding) of the chemoreceptive cells (paraganglion cells, neural crest in origin) distributed along parasympathetic nerves in the base of skull, neck, and chest

• Most common benign tumor of the temporal bone of adults (rare in pediatrics)

Glomus Vagale: arise from paraganglia around the vagus nerve at the base of skull

• SSx: pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom), hearing loss, cranial nerve palsies, aural discharge, otalgia, dizziness (invasion of the labyrinth), reddish middle ear mass, BROWN’S SIGN (BLANCHING OF THE TM WITH POSITIVE PRESSURE)

• Rx: surgical resection after preoperative embolization or primary

radiation therapy for nonoperable candidates, advanced tumors, or presence of residual disease

choices.text: BERA is the investigation of choice.

questions.text: All of the following are true about superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

BERA is the investigation of choice.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	Superior semicircular canal dehiscence is either traumatic or congenital. Patient complains of vertigo especially on hearing loud sounds (tullio’s phenomenon). 

•	Patient shows conductive hearing loss on audiometry due to leakage of sound energy from third window which has been created in SCC (apart from oval and round window). 

•	HRCT temporal bone is the diagnostic investigation. 

•	Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) is also helpful in its diagnosis.

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child on radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI has been found to having absent cochlea. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Auditory brain stem implant surgery

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•	Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation. 

•	The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel’s)

questions.text: Given finding is highly suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acoustic neuroma 

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•	The configuration of the mass is of an ‘ice cream’ cone. 

•	Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumor of glial cell origin.

•	It most commonly arises from the vestibular branch of the 8th cranial nerve.

•	It is a cause of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in adults.

•	If bilateral, the patient most likely has neurofibromatosis Type 2.

•	Important other masses occurring at the CP angle, include epidermoid cyst, pseudo tumor, metastases and lymphoma.

choices.text: Upper half paralysis of opposite side
Lower half paralysis of opposite side
Upper half paralysis of same side
Entire face on the same side is paralysed

questions.text: In a patient with Bells palsy, deviation of face is seen on which side as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Entire face on the same side is paralysed

Sol :

choices.text: Conservative management is the ideal plan

questions.text: All are true about the characteristics of Laryngomalacia except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cry is hoarse

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Laryngomalacia	=congenital	laryngeal stridor

•	Most common congenital anamoly of larynx

•	Excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx , AE folds are weak

•	Inspiratory stridor increases on crying relieved in prone position

•	Cry is normal ( Vocal cords are normal)

•	Fibreoptic laryngoscopy -- Omega shaped epiglottis and inspiratory collapse of supraglottis

•	Reassurance is sufficient in 90 % of cases rarely supraglotoplasty is required.

questions.text: Which of the following airway obstruction level causes inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Supraglottic obstruction

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

The stridor meAns noisy breathing. It is due to airway obstruction. Depending on the level of obstruction, it is of three types.

questions.text: Branchial cyst of developed due to failure of obliteration of which Pharyngeal cleft:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All

Sol :  

Congenital defects may arise as a result of disturbances of the orderly embryological development of structures originating from the primitive branchial apparatus. Defects of the second branchial apparatus have an internal opening in the Tonsillar fossa

	Abnormalities of the third branchial apparatus usually enters the pharynx at the level of the pyriform sinus 

	Defects of the fourth branchial apparatus have an internal opening in the esophagus, a fourth branchial derivative.

Vocal fold nodules

questions.text: A trumpet blower present with left sided neck swelling. X-ray reveals following finding. Most likely diagnosis of this patient:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laryngoceoele Sol : • Laryngocoele is a air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. • Aquired laryngocele: Increased pressure in the laryngeal lumen wind instrument player) • Laryngopyocele: infected laryngocele It may be: • Internal: confined within the larynx and look like distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold. • External - saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in neck. • Mixed in which both internal and external components are seen. Clinical Feature

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch. On examination vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the muscle may be involved?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin D

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	Laryngismus stridulus is primarily associated with a deficiency in vitamin D.

•	Laryngismus stridulus can be defined as laryngeal spasm caused by the sudden contraction of laryngeal muscles due to a reduced level of calcium. It is likely to be caused by vitamin D deficiency. 

•	Vitamin D, also known as cholecalciferol, plays a significant role in calcium and phosphate levels homeostasis. 

•	Its active form, calcitriol or 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is produced by sequential hydroxylation in the liver and kidneys. 

•	It primarily increases the serum calcium and phosphate levels. 

•	Deficiency of vitamin D leads to rickets.

questions.text: Gold standard test for laryngopharyngeal reflux is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

24 hour double probe pH monitoring

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Laryngopharyngeal reflux is best diag- nosed with 24 hour double probe pH mon- itoring.

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with throat pain, fever and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

Ref:Read the text below

Sol :  

•	The tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis. 

•	The referred pain may be secondary to lesions or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate or posterior one third of the tongue.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type II thyroplasty

Both vocal cords with normal mobility

Sol :  

•    Unilateral fixed cord with other cord normally mobile---T3

•    Both cords are partially mobile---T2

•    Unilateral partially mobile vocal cord with other cord normally mobile—T2

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Upper airway examination
Ref:Read the text below
Sol :  
The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions-
1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction
2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space
3. Uses a cuff to protect the airway from secretions
4. Allows suction of secretions in impaired cough reflex
5. Allows administration of anesthesia

questions.text: Patient on ICU with an Endotracheal tube. Tracheostomy is planned. Which tube should be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

PVC cuffed portex tube

Sol :  

•	Cuffed tracheostomy tubes are frequently used for patients in ICU with an endotracheal tube. 

•	The benefits commonly ascribed to tracheostomy as compared with prolonged endotracheal intubation include the following : 
 	Improved patient comfort. 
 	More effective clearance of airway secretions
 	Improved ventilatory parameters through decreased airway resistance.

questions.text: Reinke's edema leads to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dysphonia
Sol :  

•	Reinke’s edema, also called “polypoid corditis”, is a swelling of the entire layer of the superficial lamina propria (or Reinke’s layer), a structure crucial to normal voice function. It occurs almost exclusively in smokers.
•	Reinke’s edema causes a very characteristic gravelly, low-pitched voice. This is the result of swelling of the superficial lamina propria, which becomes boggy and vibrates less well as it gains in mass.

questions.text: A 3 month old child has developed persistent dyspnoea and stridor since birth. On CT scan of neck, the subglottic diameter has been found to be 2.5 mm. Subsequently , the child has been operated and a silicon tube has been placed in the airway. What is the name of this tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Montgomery’s tracheal T-tube
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
This is a case of congenital subglottic ste- nosis.

choices.text: Gives a nibbled appearance due to ulceration of the free cord margin.
Is characterized by a 'wash-leather' ulceration of the epiglottis.

questions.text: Most appropriate statement regarding pathology shown in given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Is a precancerous condition.

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

  • Repeated stripping of the cords is the usual practice unless frank carcinoma supervenes.
  • Nibbled appearance due to ulceration of the free cord margin is characteristic of tuberculous laryngitis.
  • 'Wash-leather' ulceration of the epiglottis appearance is seen in the tertiary form of acquired syphilis and represents the gummatous lesion.
  • There is a significant risk of progression to carcinoma in situ and frank invasive carcinoma.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

  • A young male with recurrent epistaxis and complaints of nasal obstruction with a mass on the nasopharynx suggests a diagnosis of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality.
  • JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours.
  • Patients usually present with a triad of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis and a mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

questions.text: Identify the prosthesis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Blom singer ( Tracheo esophageal )

  • Blom singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture device.
  • It is a one way valve surgically placed between trachea and esophagus.
  • It is used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy.
  • It  sends air from trachea to esophagus which is used to produce voice.
  • But it does not let the food particles to go from esophagus to trachea so aspiration is not significant

questions.text: 5 year old child presented to ENT OPD with the chief complaint of hoarseness of voice for last 6 months which is progressively increasing in severity. There is no history of vocal abuse. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Juvenile papilloma of larynx

  • Juvenile papillomas of larynx= recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is caused by HPV-6,11. The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth. They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs.
  • Typically seen in young children with chronic hoarseness and +- respiratory distress.
  • CO2 laser is the treatment of choice.
  • Recurrences are common after surgery. They are premalignant
  • Interferon alpha and intralesional cidofovir is helpful in management.
  • All papillomas should be examined histo- pathologically to exclude any dysplastic features or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD with a history of URTI. He also has features of mouth breathing, sleep apnoea and nasal obstruction. The mother has noticed that the child increases the volume while watching TV. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

  • The given clinical scenario of a child with mouth breathing.
  • Sleep apnoea, nasal obstruction, and decreased hearing points towards the diagnosis of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.
  • Adenoid hypertrophy causes typical facies characterized by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth, a hitched-up upper lip, prominent upper teeth causing crowding (malocclusion of teeth), a high arched hard palate (due to loss of tongue’s molding action on the palate), and a pinched-in nose due to disuse atrophy of the alae nasi.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of noisy breathing, present since a few days after birth. Inspiratory stridor is heard. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Laryngomalacia

  • The above clinical scenario of a 6-week-old child with inspiratory stridor which is relieved in the prone position is suggestive of laryngomalacia.
  • Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in children.
  • It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years.
  • Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding.
  • The cry is normal. Laryngomalacia leads to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration which results in airway obstruction.

questions.text: Enlarged orange tonsils as shown in image is found in :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) TANGIER DISEASE

  • In tangier disease there is a DEFECT IN EFFLUX OF CELLULAR CHOLESTEROL, leading to cholesterol accumulation in reticuloendothelial cells.
  • ENLARGE ORANGE TONSILS are pathognomonic of tangier disease.

questions.text: A child with throat pain and fever has been found to have whitish membrane in the Tonsillar region which bleeds on scrapping. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Diphtheric Tonsillitis

choices.text: Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Sensorineural Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Retro-orbital pain, Conductive Hearing Loss

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Trotter's Triad
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss

  • Trotter’s triad is a unique symptom complex associated with infiltrative malignant tumours invading the lateral wall of nasopharynx or a lesion arising in the region of sinus of Morgagni.
  • Pathognomonic features in sequential order include ipsilateral conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube block, trigeminal nerve neuralgia affecting the mandibular division initially and anaesthesia later, secondary to its invasion in foramen ovale, and palatal asymmetry owing to ipsilateral direct infiltration of levator palatini muscles.

questions.text: A child presents with history of foreign body ingestion.The X-ray picture is given in the image. What is the possible site of foreign body impaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oesophagus

questions.text: Which of the following staging systems is used in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Fisch staging system

  • The Fisch staging system is used in the case of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibromas.
